qas.question: What kind of pesticide is DDT?
Why have DDTs been banned in some areas?

answers.text: persistence in the environment and human toxicity
DDT use is not always effective

qas.question: How may species have been found to be resistant to DDT?
When were 19 new species of mosquito discovered in Africa?
How long has DDT been banned worldwide?

plausible_answers.text: have given stronger support to this approach

qas.question: How supportive is Africa about DDT being banned?
In what year was DDT first invented?
When were mosquitoes first discovered to carry Malaria?

context: DDT, sprayed on the walls of houses, is <a0_0>an organochlorine<a0_0/> that has been used to fight malaria <b5_0>since the 1950s<b5_0/>. Recent policy statements by the World Health Organization <b6_0>have given stronger support to this approach<b6_0/>. However, DDT and other organochlorine pesticides have been banned in most countries worldwide because of their <a1_0>persistence in the environment and human toxicity<a1_0/>. <a2_0>DDT use is not always effective<a2_0/>, as resistance to DDT was identified in Africa as early as <b7_0>1955<b7_0/>, and by <b4_0><b8_0>1972<b8_0/><b4_0/> <a3_0>nineteen<a3_0/> species of mosquito worldwide were resistant to DDT.
